summary: An FBI Miami Division request form to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) for scanning and processing telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager. The records are from an address book Rodriguez possessed, believed to contain contacts of additional underage victims of Epstein, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice case
persons.context: The subject of the FBI investigation for obstruction of justice. He was Epstein's house manager and came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referenced as the individual to whom Alfredo Rodriguez was employed and whose alleged underage victims' contact information was contained in the address book Rodriguez possessed.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez came into possession of an address book believed to contain contact information for Epstein's potential underage victims, linking him to the core of the investigation.

events.title: Miami Division opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: The FBI Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 22, 2010) are relevant to the investigation.

locations: Winchester, Virginia (Location of the FBI Document Conversion Laboratory)
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, was under FBI investigation for obstruction of justice since October 2009.
Rodriguez possessed an address book containing names and telephone numbers believed to belong to additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez attempted to sell this address book rather than turn it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

The FBI was processing telephone records from this address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for incorporation into its Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.
The document is an internal FBI request form to scan and automate these telephone records for investigative use.
